sect1.title: Synopsis
sect1.para: The Workflow Editor is the main view where you can define your workflow logic by adding components and connecting them.

sect1.title: Options

listitem.para: Show grid: A grid overlay is shown when the toolbar entry "Show grid" is activated. Components, labels and connections' bendpoints snap to the grid. Having "Alt" pressed while dragging omits the snapping.
Snap to geometry: Components and labels snap to each other when the toolbar entry "Snap to geometry" is activated. Again, pressing "Alt" while dragging omits the snapping.

Fore- and background: You can send components and labels to back- or foreground using the context menu entries "Send Back", "Send Forward", "Send to Background" and "Send to Foreground". While the first two entries change the layer by one, the latter two put it to the front or to the back. Note that workflow components and labels are treated separately, i.e. components are always in front of labels.

Number of connections: The number of connections bundled within a single arrow can be shown. To see it either select a connection or select the toolbar entry "Show number of connections in workflow editor".

Custom connection paths: They can be defined by selecting a connection and dragging the dot. You can reset the custom connection path in the context menu of the connection by clicking the entry "Reset Connection Path". Ctrl + Delete is the shortcut for resetting the connection path.

Disable/Enable workflow components: In a component's context menu you can disable components so they are ignored when you execute the workflow. That can be useful when you are in the process of creating the workflow and temporarily just want to execute a part of the workflow. Disabled components are greyed out.

Disable/Enable tool run imitation mode: User integrated tools can be configured to support a tool run imitation mode. This can be useful if you want to get your workflow logic straight but don't want to run the actual tool every time. In the context menu of an integrated component you can enable or diabled this mode. If the tool run imitation mode is enabled the component appears in blue and has an "I" for "Imitation" at the bottom right edge.

Open documentation: User integrated tools can be configured to have a text or PDF file as documentation. If there is such a documentation the context menu entry "Open documentation" will open it in an editor, otherwise a message is shown.
Undo/Redo: You can undo and redo actions in the workflow editor. It is restricted to 10 actions for technical reasons.

Zooming: To zoom in and out a workflow, one can use the view menu entries or the corresponding keyboard shortcuts as well as the buttons or the zoom level combo box in the toolbar. The zoom level combo box also provides some zoom levels to fit the workflow into the currently available space.
The zoom level is restricted to a minimum value of 10% and a maximum of 200%, even though a zoom level like 'Fit Workflow' is selected.
Image file export: You can export a workflow as an image file by selecting the "Export as Image..." entry in the file menu. Supported file formats are BMP, JPG and PNG.

sect1.para: Note that there is also a read-only pendant of the Workflow Editor, where you can inspect a workflow without editing it. Workflows opened from the Workflow Data Browser get displayed this way. Additionally, Workflows can also be opened read-only from the Project Explorer by selecting "Open With"->"Read-only Workflow Editor".
